claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

verified_evidence.quote: Although embryonated hen's eggs have been used to generate effective influenza vaccines for many years, this system does have several important drawbacks. Vaccine manufacturing using eggs requires specialized facilities, and the ability to scale up egg production, growth in eggs, a process that can be time consuming, is not always successful, and which can select receptor variants that may not be optimally representative of circulating influenza strains [1,2].
verified_evidence.explanation: The quote appears on the first page of the document, with only minor formatting and OCR-related differences. The key factual content is present: 'Although embryonated hen's eggs have been used to generate effective influenza vaccines for many years, this system does have several important drawbacks. Vaccine manufacturing using eggs requires specialized facilities, and the ability to scale up egg pro growth in eggs, a process that can be time consuming, is not always successful, and which can select receptor variants that may not be optimally representative of circulating influenza strains [1,2].' The extracted quote is semantically equivalent to the provided quote.. The quote directly supports the claim. It explicitly states that the process of growing influenza vaccines in eggs 'can select receptor variants that may not be optimally representative of circulating influenza strains.' This means that mutations or changes can occur during production, potentially making the vaccine less effective against the actual circulating viruses. This is exactly what the claim asserts: that cell- and egg-based flu vaccines can develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
verified_evidence.presence_explanation: The quote appears on the first page of the document, with only minor formatting and OCR-related differences. The key factual content is present: 'Although embryonated hen's eggs have been used to generate effective influenza vaccines for many years, this system does have several important drawbacks. Vaccine manufacturing using eggs requires specialized facilities, and the ability to scale up egg pro growth in eggs, a process that can be time consuming, is not always successful, and which can select receptor variants that may not be optimally representative of circulating influenza strains [1,2].' The extracted quote is semantically equivalent to the provided quote.
verified_evidence.support_explanation: The quote directly supports the claim. It explicitly states that the process of growing influenza vaccines in eggs 'can select receptor variants that may not be optimally representative of circulating influenza strains.' This means that mutations or changes can occur during production, potentially making the vaccine less effective against the actual circulating viruses. This is exactly what the claim asserts: that cell- and egg-based flu vaccines can develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
verified_evidence.original_relevance: This quote explicitly states that egg-based vaccine production can select for receptor variants that may not match circulating strains, supporting the claim that mutations can develop during production and reduce effectiveness.

new_evidence.quote: Estimates of overall inactivated vaccine protective efficacy are clearly impacted by antigenic differences between vaccine and circulating viruses, with highest levels of effectiveness reported for H1 viruses [25] and lowest levels for influenza B.
new_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote supports the claim by explicitly stating that antigenic differences (which can arise from mutations during production) between the vaccine and circulating viruses impact the effectiveness of inactivated (egg- or cell-based) influenza vaccines.

new_evidence.quote: Effectiveness of inactivated influenza vaccines varied substantially with antigenic match from the 2004-2005 season to the 2006-2007 season. J Infect Dis 2009 199.
new_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote provides evidence that the effectiveness of inactivated (egg- or cell-based) influenza vaccines is affected by how well the vaccine antigens match circulating strains, which can be reduced by mutations acquired during production.

new_evidence.quote: Clinical efficacy of cell culture derived and egg derived inactivated subunit influenza vaccines in healthy adults. Clin Infect Dis 2010 51 997 1004.
new_evidence.relevance_explanation: This reference to a study comparing cell culture and egg-derived vaccines is relevant because such studies often discuss the impact of production-related mutations on vaccine efficacy, supporting the claim that these vaccines can develop mutations that reduce effectiveness.
